Tidy simpr_gen simulated model results output into tibble of model summaries

Source: R/glance_fits.R
glance_fits.Rd

Turn fitted model of simulated data (from fit.simpr_tibble) into a tidy tibble of model summaries (via generics::glance).

glance_fits(obj, ..., .progress = FALSE, .options = furrr_options())

Arguments

obj

tibble with repetition number, metaparameters, simulated data, and fitted models, from fit.simpr_tibble
...

Additional arguments to generics::glance.
.progress

A logical, for whether or not to print a progress bar for multiprocess, multisession, and multicore plans .
.options

The future specific options to use with the workers when using futures. This must be the result from a call to furrr_options().

Value

a tibble with the output of the generics::glance method for the given object.

Details

This is part of the fifth step of the simulation process: after fitting the model with fit.simpr_tibble, now tidy the model output for further analysis such as evaluating power. All model objects should be supported by generics::glance, primarily via the broom package.

The output of this function is quite useful for calculating things overall model fit; see Examples. For looking at specific features of the model such as tests for individual parameter estimates, use tidy_fits.

See also

tidy_fits to view model components (e.g. parameter estimates), apply_fits to apply an arbitrary function to the fits

Examples

simple_linear_data = specify(x1 = ~ 2 + rnorm(n),
          y = ~ 5 + 3 * x1 + rnorm(n, 0, sd = 0.5)) %>%
  define(n = 100:101) %>%
  generate(2)

## Can show glance output for multiple competing models,
compare_degree = simple_linear_data %>%
  fit(linear = ~lm(y ~ x1, data = .),
      quadratic = ~lm(y ~ x1 + I(x1^2), data = .)) %>%
  glance_fits

## Models can be of different types -- anything supported by broom::glance.
cor_vs_lm = simple_linear_data %>%
  fit(linear = ~lm(y ~ x1, data = .),
      cor = ~ cor.test(.$y, .$x1)) %>%
  glance_fits

cor_vs_lm # has NA for non-matching terms

#> # A tibble: 8 × 22
#>   .sim_id     n   rep Source r.squared adj.r.squared  sigma statistic  p.value
#>     <int> <int> <int> <chr>      <dbl>         <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>
#> 1       1   100     1 linear     0.969         0.969  0.547    3063.  9.82e-76
#> 2       1   100     1 cor       NA            NA     NA          55.3 9.82e-76
#> 3       2   101     1 linear     0.975         0.975  0.504    3921.  1.91e-81
#> 4       2   101     1 cor       NA            NA     NA          62.6 1.91e-81
#> 5       3   100     2 linear     0.973         0.973  0.471    3528.  1.17e-78
#> 6       3   100     2 cor       NA            NA     NA          59.4 1.17e-78
#> 7       4   101     2 linear     0.973         0.973  0.515    3617.  9.45e-80
#> 8       4   101     2 cor       NA            NA     NA          60.1 9.45e-80
#> # … with 13 more variables: df <dbl>, logLik <dbl>, AIC <dbl>, BIC <dbl>,
#> #   deviance <dbl>, df.residual <int>, nobs <int>, estimate <dbl>,
#> #   parameter <int>, conf.low <dbl>, conf.high <dbl>, method <chr>,
#> #   alternative <chr>

## Example power analysis to detect an interaction (g1)
set.seed(100)
simpr_glance = ## Specify the simulation
  specify(x1 = ~ 2 + rnorm(n),
            x2 = ~ 3 + 2*x1 + rnorm(n, 0, sd = 0.5),
            y = ~ 5 + x1 + x2 + g1*x1*x2 + 10 * rnorm(n)) %>%
  define(n = seq(100, 300, by = 20),
       g1 = seq(-1, 1, by = 0.5)) %>%
  ## Generate the data
  generate(10) %>%
  ## Fit models
  fit(lm = ~lm(y ~ x1*x2, data = .)) %>%
  ## Calculate the output
  glance_fits

## Now we can easily calculate and plot r.squared by model
library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’:
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’:
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(ggplot2)
simpr_glance %>%
  group_by(n, g1) %>%
  summarize(mean_r_squared = mean(r.squared)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(n, mean_r_squared)) +
  geom_line() +
  facet_grid(~g1) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0,1))

#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'n'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
